Red Bull Racing F1 Team

Created by Rohan Mittal

This article is about the Formula One Team. For the NASCAR team, see RedBull Racing team.
For more information about RedBull see
RedBull

Introduction

Red Bull Racing, also simply known as Red Bull or RBR and currently competing as Oracle Red Bull Racing is a Formula One racing team, racing under Austrian license and based in the United Kingdom.

The Red Bull Racing team has been managed by Christian Horner since its formation in 2005. Red Bull has had Cosworth and Ferrari engines in 2006.

The current driver lineup consists of Max Vertsappen and Sergio Perez.

Contents

  1. History
  2. Origins
  3. Cosworth Engines
  4. Ferrari engines
  5. Renault engines
  6. Honda Engines
  7. Seasons

History

The current Red Bull team can trace its origins back to the Stewart Grand Prix outfit that made its debut in 1997. Red Bull, an energy drinks company, agreed its purchase of Jaguar racing on the final day of the sale. Red Bull Racing was not the start of Red Bull's involvement in Formula One, as they sponsored Sauber from 1995 to 2004.

Cosworth Engines

Red Bull Racing used Cosworth engines in its maiden year due to the ease of continuing with the engine Jaguar Racing used.

Ferrari Engines

On 23 April 2005, the team announced a deal to utilise customer Ferrari engines in 2006. This coincided with a rule change mandating the use of V8 engines, making it likely that both Red Bull racing and Ferrari would use the same specification engine.

V8 engine is an eight- cylinder piston engine in which two banks of four cylinders share a common crankshaft and are arranged in a V configuration.

Renault Engines (2007- 2015)

The team announced on 31 August 2006 they would use customer Renault engines for the 2007 season.

Honda Engines (2019- 2021)

Red Bull Racing confirmed they are utilizing full works Honda power units from 2019 to 2020, signing a two-year deal and thus ending their twelve year partnership with Renault.

Red Bull Racing have been one of the most successful teams in Formula One.
